item.title: SEO Implementation Guide
item.description: This document outlines the comprehensive SEO implementation added to the Next.js application using next-sitemap and next-seo packages.
item.content:encoded:
This document outlines the comprehensive SEO implementation added to the Next.js application using next-sitemap and next-seo packages.

📋 Overview​

The SEO implementation includes:

  • Sitemap Generation with next-sitemap
  • Meta Tags Management with next-seo
  • Structured Data (JSON-LD) support
  • Multilingual SEO for English and Vietnamese
  • Social Media Optimization (OpenGraph, Twitter Cards)
  • SEO Health Monitoring tools

🗂️ File Structure​

src/
├── config/
│   ├── seo.ts              # Default SEO configuration
│   └── seo-pages.ts        # Page-specific SEO configurations
├── components/
│   ├── SEOWrapper.tsx      # Global SEO wrapper component
│   └── PageSEO.tsx         # Page-specific SEO components
├── hooks/
│   └── useSEO.ts          # SEO utility hooks
└── app/
    └── [locale]/
        └── layout.tsx      # Updated with SEO integration

Configuration Files:
├── next-sitemap.config.js  # Sitemap generation configuration
└── scripts/
    └── seo-health-check.js # SEO monitoring script

🔧 Core Components​

1. Default SEO Configuration (src/config/seo.ts)​

export const defaultSEO: DefaultSeoProps = {
  titleTemplate: '%s | Next.js Production App',
  defaultTitle: 'Next.js Production App',
  description: 'A production-ready Next.js application with modern features...',
  openGraph: {
    type: 'website',
    locale: 'en_US',
    url: 'https://next-for-prod.com/',
    siteName: 'Next.js Production App',
    images: [{ url: '/og-default.jpg', width: 1200, height: 630 }]
  },
  twitter: {
    handle: '@nextjsprod',
    site: '@nextjsprod',
    cardType: 'summary_large_image'
  }
};

2. Page-Specific SEO (src/config/seo-pages.ts)​

Provides localized SEO configurations for all major pages:

  • Home, About, Libraries, Tools, Calendar, Posts, Feedback
  • Authentication pages (Login, Signup)
  • Multilingual support (English/Vietnamese)
  • Canonical URLs and language alternates

3. SEO Components (src/components/PageSEO.tsx)​

// Specialized components for each page type
<HomeSEO />
<AboutSEO />
<LibsSEO />
<ArticleSEO 
  title="Article Title"
  description="Article description"
  url="https://example.com/article"
  datePublished="2024-01-01"
  image="/article-image.jpg"
/>

4. SEO Hooks (src/hooks/useSEO.ts)​

// Automatic SEO based on current route
const seoConfig = useSEO();

// Manual page specification
const seoConfig = useSEO('home');

// Get canonical URL
const canonicalUrl = useCanonicalUrl();

// Generate structured data
const organizationData = useStructuredData('organization');

🗺️ Sitemap Configuration​

next-sitemap.config.js​

module.exports = {
  siteUrl: process.env.SITE_URL || 'https://yourdomain.com',
  generateRobotstxt: true,
  sitemapSize: 7000,
  changefreq: 'daily',
  priority: 0.7,
  additionalPaths: async (config) => {
    // 29 URLs total with multilingual support
    // Static pages, dynamic routes, auth pages
  },
  robotsTxtOptions: {
    policies: [
      { userAgent: '*', allow: '/' },
      { userAgent: 'GPTBot', disallow: ['/'] },
      { userAgent: 'ChatGPT-User', disallow: ['/'] },
      { userAgent: 'CCBot', disallow: ['/'] }
    ]
  }
};

Generated Files​

  • public/sitemap.xml: 29 URLs with proper priorities and change frequencies
  • public/robots.txt: AI crawler blocking and sitemap references

🌐 Multilingual SEO​

Each page supports both English and Vietnamese with:

  • Localized titles and descriptions
  • Proper hreflang attributes
  • Language-specific OpenGraph images
  • Canonical URLs for each locale
// English
canonical: `${BASE_URL}/en/about`
hreflang: [
  { hrefLang: 'en', href: `${BASE_URL}/en/about` },
  { hrefLang: 'vi', href: `${BASE_URL}/vi/about` },
  { hrefLang: 'x-default', href: `${BASE_URL}/en/about` }
]

// Vietnamese  
canonical: `${BASE_URL}/vi/about`
locale: 'vi_VN'

📊 Structured Data Support​

Organization Schema​

{
  "@context": "https://schema.org",
  "@type": "Organization",
  "name": "Next.js Production App",
  "url": "https://next-for-prod.com",
  "logo": "https://next-for-prod.com/logo.png"
}

Article Schema​

{
  "@context": "https://schema.org",
  "@type": "Article",
  "headline": "Article Title",
  "datePublished": "2024-01-01",
  "author": { "@type": "Person", "name": "Author Name" }
}

Breadcrumb Schema​

{
  "@context": "https://schema.org",
  "@type": "BreadcrumbList",
  "itemListElement": [...]
}

🚀 Usage Examples​

1. Basic Page SEO​

import { HomeSEO } from '@/components/PageSEO';

export default function HomePage() {
  return (
    <>
      <HomeSEO />
      <main>
        {/* Page content */}
      </main>
    </>
  );
}

2. Custom SEO Override​

import { PageSEO } from '@/components/PageSEO';

export default function CustomPage() {
  return (
    <>
      <PageSEO 
        pageKey="home"
        customSEO={{
          title: 'Custom Title',
          description: 'Custom description'
        }}
      />
      <main>
        {/* Page content */}
      </main>
    </>
  );
}

3. Article with Structured Data​

import { ArticleSEO } from '@/components/PageSEO';

export default function BlogPost() {
  return (
    <>
      <ArticleSEO
        title="How to Build Production-Ready Next.js Apps"
        description="Complete guide to building scalable Next.js applications"
        url="https://next-for-prod.com/en/posts/production-nextjs"
        datePublished="2024-01-15"
        authorName="Development Team"
        image="/posts/production-nextjs-og.jpg"
      />
      <article>
        {/* Article content */}
      </article>
    </>
  );
}

🔍 SEO Health Monitoring​

Health Check Script (scripts/seo-health-check.js)​

node scripts/seo-health-check.js

Validates:

  • ✅ Sitemap accessibility
  • ✅ Robots.txt functionality
  • ✅ Page response codes
  • ✅ Meta tag presence
  • ✅ OpenGraph data
  • ✅ Structured data validation

🛠️ Build Integration​

The sitemap automatically regenerates on every build:

{
  "scripts": {
    "build": "next build",
    "postbuild": "next-sitemap"
  }
}

📈 SEO Features Summary​

FeatureStatusDescription
Sitemap Generation✅29 URLs with multilingual support
Robots.txt✅AI crawler blocking, sitemap references
Meta Tags✅Title, description, viewport, theme-color
OpenGraph✅Facebook, LinkedIn sharing optimization
Twitter Cards✅Twitter sharing optimization
Structured Data✅Organization, Article, Breadcrumb schemas
Multilingual✅English/Vietnamese with hreflang
Canonical URLs✅Proper URL canonicalization
Health Monitoring✅Automated SEO validation

🎯 Best Practices Implemented​

  1. Title Templates: Consistent branding across all pages
  2. Unique Descriptions: Each page has specific, descriptive meta descriptions
  3. Image Optimization: 1200x630 OpenGraph images for optimal sharing
  4. Mobile Optimization: Proper viewport and mobile meta tags
  5. Accessibility: Alt text for images, proper heading structure
  6. Performance: Minimal SEO overhead, efficient component structure
  7. Internationalization: Proper language declarations and alternates

🔮 Future Enhancements​

  • Video Structured Data for video content
  • FAQ Schema for help pages
  • Local Business Schema if applicable
  • Product Schema for e-commerce features
  • Review Schema for user-generated content
  • Event Schema for calendar integration
  • Advanced Analytics integration
  • Core Web Vitals monitoring

📚 References​

  • next-seo Documentation
  • next-sitemap Documentation
  • Google Search Console Guidelines
  • Schema.org Documentation
  • OpenGraph Protocol
  • Twitter Card Validator

🎉 Your Next.js application now has enterprise-grade SEO implementation!

The setup includes comprehensive sitemap generation, meta tag management, structured data, and multilingual support. All major search engines can now properly index and display your content in search results and social media platforms.

item.title: SEO Setup with next-sitemap
item.description: This project uses next-sitemap to generate SEO-optimized sitemaps and robots.txt files.
item.content:encoded:
This project uses next-sitemap to generate SEO-optimized sitemaps and robots.txt files.

Features​

✅ Automatic Sitemap Generation: Generates comprehensive sitemaps for all public routes
✅ Multi-language Support: Full support for English (en) and Vietnamese (vi) locales
✅ Robots.txt Generation: Automatic robots.txt with AI crawler blocking
✅ SEO Optimization: Proper priorities, change frequencies, and hreflang attributes
✅ Build Integration: Automatically runs after each build

Configuration​

Environment Variables​

Set your production domain in your environment:

# .env.local or .env.production
NEXT_PUBLIC_APP_URL=https://next-for-prod.com

Routes Included​

The sitemap includes these public routes for both locales:

  • Homepage: /en, /vi (Priority: 1.0, Daily updates)
  • Content Pages: /about, /libs, /posts, /calendar (High priority)
  • Tools: /tools, /search-*, /roadmap/* (Medium priority)
  • Auth Pages: /login, /signup (Lower priority)
  • Utility Pages: /feedback (Medium priority)

Routes Excluded​

These routes are excluded from search engines:

  • Admin pages (/admin/*)
  • User profiles (/profile/*, /me/*)
  • Private settings (/settings)
  • API routes (/api/*)
  • Test pages (/test-*)
  • Authentication callbacks (/auth/*)
  • Edit/create forms

Usage​

Generate Sitemap​

# Manual generation
pnpm sitemap:generate

# Automatic generation after build
pnpm build  # Runs next-sitemap via postbuild script

Generated Files​

  • public/sitemap.xml - Main sitemap with all URLs
  • public/robots.txt - Search engine directives

SEO Utilities​

The project includes SEO utilities in src/utils/seo.ts:

import { generatePageSEO } from '@/utils/seo';

export const metadata = generatePageSEO('home', 'en');

Available functions:

  • generateSEOMetadata() - Comprehensive metadata generation
  • generatePageSEO() - Page-specific SEO metadata
  • generateStructuredData() - JSON-LD structured data

AI Crawler Blocking​

The robots.txt automatically blocks these AI crawlers:

  • GPTBot
  • ChatGPT-User
  • CCBot
  • anthropic-ai
  • Claude-Web

Monitoring​

Google Search Console​

  1. Submit your sitemap: https://yourdomain.com/sitemap.xml
  2. Monitor indexing status
  3. Check for crawl errors

Validation Tools​

  • Google Rich Results Test
  • Bing Webmaster Tools
  • XML Sitemap Validator

Configuration File​

Edit next-sitemap.config.js to:

  • Add new routes
  • Modify priorities and change frequencies
  • Update hreflang mappings
  • Exclude additional paths

Best Practices​

  1. Update sitemap after major changes: Run pnpm sitemap:generate
  2. Monitor crawl budget: Use robots.txt to guide crawlers to important pages
  3. Regular audits: Check for 404s and crawl errors
  4. Performance: Exclude dynamic/user-specific pages from sitemap
  5. Localization: Ensure hreflang attributes are correct for international SEO

Troubleshooting​

Sitemap not updating​

  • Run pnpm build to regenerate
  • Check next-sitemap.config.js for syntax errors
  • Verify environment variables

Routes missing from sitemap​

  • Add to additionalPaths in config
  • Check exclusion rules
  • Ensure pages are statically accessible

robots.txt issues​

  • Verify generateRobotsTxt: true in config
  • Check policy rules for conflicts
  • Test with robots.txt validators

item.title: Elasticsearch Full-Text Search Setup
item.description: This guide will help you set up Elasticsearch for full-text search functionality in your Next.js application.
item.content:encoded:
This guide will help you set up Elasticsearch for full-text search functionality in your Next.js application.

Prerequisites​

  • Node.js and npm/yarn installed
  • Next.js application running
  • Supabase database with posts

1. Install Elasticsearch​

Option A: Using Docker (Recommended for development)​

# Start Elasticsearch with Docker
docker run -d \
  --name elasticsearch \
  -p 9200:9200 \
  -e "discovery.type=single-node" \
  -e "xpack.security.enabled=false" \
  elasticsearch:8.11.0

# Verify Elasticsearch is running
curl http://localhost:9200

Option B: Local Installation​

  1. Download Elasticsearch from elastic.co
  2. Follow the installation guide for your operating system
  3. Start Elasticsearch service

2. Environment Variables​

Add these environment variables to your .env.local file:

# Elasticsearch Configuration
ELASTICSEARCH_URL=http://localhost:9200
ELASTICSEARCH_POSTS_INDEX=posts

# Optional: Authentication (if your Elasticsearch requires auth)
# ELASTICSEARCH_USERNAME=your_username
# ELASTICSEARCH_PASSWORD=your_password
# ELASTICSEARCH_APIKEY=your_api_key

3. Initialize the Index​

Option A: Using the Web Interface (Development)​

  1. Go to your posts page (/posts)
  2. In the debug section, click "Check Status" to verify Elasticsearch connection
  3. Click "Initialize Index" to create the index and bulk import existing posts

Option B: Using the Setup Script​

# Run the setup script
npx tsx scripts/setup-elasticsearch.ts

# Or add to package.json scripts:
# "setup:elasticsearch": "tsx scripts/setup-elasticsearch.ts"
# Then run: npm run setup:elasticsearch

Option C: Using the API Endpoint​

# Check Elasticsearch status
curl http://localhost:3000/api/elasticsearch/init

# Initialize the index
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/api/elasticsearch/init

4. Features​

Search Functionality​

  • Full-text search: Search across post titles and content
  • Fuzzy matching: Handles typos and similar words
  • Highlighting: Search terms are highlighted in results
  • Fallback: Falls back to database search if Elasticsearch is unavailable
  • Responsive: Search bar available in navbar on desktop and mobile

Search Features​

  • Keyboard shortcut: Press Cmd+K (Mac) or Ctrl+K (Windows/Linux) to focus search
  • Real-time results: Search results update as you type
  • Pagination: Large result sets are paginated
  • Sorting: Results sorted by relevance score and creation date

5. API Endpoints​

Search Posts​

GET /api/posts/search?q=search_term&page=1&limit=10

Initialize Elasticsearch​

GET /api/elasticsearch/init    # Check status
POST /api/elasticsearch/init   # Initialize index

Sync Posts to Elasticsearch​

GET /api/elasticsearch/sync     # Health check and endpoints info
POST /api/elasticsearch/sync?action=sync   # Sync all posts
POST /api/elasticsearch/sync?action=health # Health check only

6. Automatic Indexing​

Posts are automatically indexed in Elasticsearch when:

  • Creating a post: New posts are indexed immediately after successful creation
  • Updating a post: Modified posts are re-indexed with the latest content
  • Deleting a post: Posts are removed from the Elasticsearch index

The indexing happens automatically in the background and won't affect the user experience. If Elasticsearch is unavailable, the database operations will still succeed, and only a warning will be logged.

Manual Sync​

If you need to sync existing posts or re-index everything:

Using the API​

# Check Elasticsearch health
curl http://localhost:3000/api/elasticsearch/sync

# Sync all posts to Elasticsearch
curl -X POST "http://localhost:3000/api/elasticsearch/sync?action=sync"

# Health check only
curl -X POST "http://localhost:3000/api/elasticsearch/sync?action=health"

Using the Sync Service​

import { syncPostsToElasticsearch } from '@/shared/services/sync';

const result = await syncPostsToElasticsearch();
console.log(`Synced ${result.syncedCount} posts`);

Monitoring Indexing​

During development, you can monitor indexing in the browser console:

  • ✅ Post indexed in Elasticsearch: 123
  • ✅ Post updated in Elasticsearch: 123
  • ✅ Post deleted from Elasticsearch: 123
  • ⚠️ Failed to index post in Elasticsearch: [error details]

7. Troubleshooting​

Elasticsearch not connecting​

  1. Verify Elasticsearch is running: curl http://localhost:9200
  2. Check environment variables in .env.local
  3. Check Docker container status: docker ps
  4. View Docker logs: docker logs elasticsearch

Search not working​

  1. Check if index exists: Use the debug panel in /posts
  2. Verify posts are indexed: Look for "posts indexed" message
  3. Check browser console for JavaScript errors
  4. Verify API endpoints are working

Performance Issues​

  1. Increase Elasticsearch memory: Add -e "ES_JAVA_OPTS=-Xms512m -Xmx512m" to Docker command
  2. Optimize search queries in elasticsearch.ts
  3. Implement caching for frequently searched terms

8. Production Deployment​

Elasticsearch Service​

For production, consider using:

  • Elastic Cloud: Managed Elasticsearch service
  • AWS OpenSearch: Amazon's Elasticsearch service
  • Self-hosted: Deploy Elasticsearch on your own infrastructure

Environment Variables for Production​

ELASTICSEARCH_URL=https://your-production-elasticsearch-url
ELASTICSEARCH_APIKEY=your-production-api-key
ELASTICSEARCH_POSTS_INDEX=production_posts

Security Considerations​

  1. Enable authentication on Elasticsearch
  2. Use HTTPS for Elasticsearch connections
  3. Restrict network access to Elasticsearch
  4. Regularly update Elasticsearch version

9. Monitoring and Maintenance​

Health Checks​

The application includes health checks:

  • Elasticsearch availability check in search API
  • Fallback to database search if Elasticsearch is down
  • Status indicators in development debug panel

Index Maintenance​

  • Reindexing: Use the initialize endpoint to rebuild the index
  • Mapping updates: Update the mapping in elasticsearch.ts and reinitialize
  • Performance monitoring: Monitor query performance and optimize as needed

10. Customization​

Search Configuration​

Edit src/shared/services/elasticsearch.ts to customize:

  • Search fields and boost values
  • Highlighting settings
  • Fuzzy matching sensitivity
  • Result sorting criteria

UI Customization​

Edit components to customize:

  • src/shared/ui/search-bar/index.tsx: Search bar appearance
  • src/features/posts/list/ui.tsx: Results display
  • src/app/[locale]/components/Navbar.tsx: Navbar integration

Support​

If you encounter issues:

  1. Check the troubleshooting section above
  2. Review Elasticsearch logs
  3. Check browser console for errors
  4. Verify environment variables are set correctly

item.title: Social Login Setup (Google & GitHub)
item.description: This document explains how to set up Google and GitHub OAuth providers in your Supabase project.
item.content:encoded:
This document explains how to set up Google and GitHub OAuth providers in your Supabase project.

🔧 Supabase Configuration​

1. Google OAuth Setup​

  1. Create Google OAuth App:

    • Go to Google Cloud Console
    • Create a new project or select existing one
    • Enable Google+ API
    • Go to "Credentials" → "Create Credentials" → "OAuth 2.0 Client IDs"
    • Choose "Web application"
    • Add authorized redirect URIs: 
      https://your-project-ref.supabase.co/auth/v1/callback

  2. Configure in Supabase:

    • Go to your Supabase project dashboard
    • Navigate to "Authentication" → "Providers"
    • Enable "Google"
    • Add your Google Client ID and Client Secret
    • Save configuration

2. GitHub OAuth Setup​

  1. Create GitHub OAuth App:

    • Go to GitHub Settings → Developer settings → OAuth Apps
    • Click "New OAuth App"
    • Fill in the details:
      • Application name: Your app name
      • Homepage URL: Your app URL
      • Authorization callback URL: 
        https://your-project-ref.supabase.co/auth/v1/callback

  2. Configure in Supabase:

    • Go to your Supabase project dashboard
    • Navigate to "Authentication" → "Providers"
    • Enable "GitHub"
    • Add your GitHub Client ID and Client Secret
    • Save configuration

🚀 Implementation Features​

Frontend Components​

  • Login Form (src/features/auth/login-form/ui.tsx):

    • Google login button with brand colors
    • GitHub login button
    • Loading states and error handling
    • Disabled state during authentication

  • OAuth Callback (src/app/[locale]/auth/callback/route.ts):

    • Handles OAuth redirects from providers
    • Exchanges authorization codes for sessions
    • Redirects with success/error messages

User Experience​

  1. Login Flow:

    • User clicks Google/GitHub button
    • Redirected to provider's authorization page
    • After approval, redirected back to /auth/callback
    • Session established and redirected to home page

  2. Error Handling:

    • Provider authentication failures
    • Network errors
    • Invalid callback requests
    • User-friendly error messages

🔒 Security Features​

  • PKCE Flow: Uses Proof Key for Code Exchange for security
  • State Validation: Prevents CSRF attacks
  • Secure Redirects: Only allows authorized redirect URLs
  • Session Management: Proper cookie handling and session storage

🎨 UI/UX Improvements​

  • Brand Colors: Google (red) and GitHub (gray) themed buttons
  • Loading States: Buttons disabled during authentication
  • Clear Messaging: Success and error feedback
  • Responsive Design: Works on mobile and desktop

📝 Usage Notes​

  • Make sure to configure your OAuth apps with the correct callback URLs
  • Test both providers in development and production environments
  • The callback route handles both success and error cases
  • Users will be redirected to the home page after successful login

🐛 Troubleshooting​

  1. "Invalid redirect URI": Check your OAuth app callback URLs
  2. "Client ID not found": Verify Supabase provider configuration
  3. "Authentication failed": Check provider app permissions and status
  4. Session not persisting: Verify cookie settings and domain configuration

item.title: Introducing Next.js for Production
item.description: We're excited to introduce Next.js for Production - a comprehensive, enterprise-grade Next.js application that demonstrates best practices, modern architecture, and production-ready features.
item.content:encoded:
We're excited to introduce Next.js for Production - a comprehensive, enterprise-grade Next.js application that demonstrates best practices, modern architecture, and production-ready features.

What Makes This Project Special?​

🏗️ Modern Architecture​

Our project follows a clean, scalable architecture based on:

  • Atomic Design: Components are organized into atoms, molecules, organisms, and templates
  • Feature-Based Structure: Each major feature is self-contained with its own components, hooks, and services
  • TypeScript First: Complete type safety across the entire application
  • Domain-Driven Design: Clear separation of business logic and presentation layers

🔐 Enterprise Security​

Security is built into every layer:

  • Authentication: Multi-provider auth with Supabase
  • Authorization: Role-based access control (RBAC) with row-level security
  • Input Validation: Zod schemas for runtime type checking
  • Rate Limiting: API protection with Arcjet
  • Security Headers: Comprehensive security headers configuration

📊 Real-World Features​

The application includes features you'd find in production applications:

  • Calendar System: Advanced calendar with recurring events and real-time updates
  • Library Management: Elasticsearch-powered search with faceted filtering
  • User Management: Complete user lifecycle with profiles and preferences
  • Internationalization: Multi-language support with next-intl
  • Real-time Updates: WebSocket integration for live data synchronization

Technical Highlights​

Performance First​

  • Core Web Vitals: Optimized for all performance metrics
  • Image Optimization: Next.js Image component with CDN integration
  • Code Splitting: Automatic route-based and component-based splitting
  • Caching Strategy: Multi-layer caching with Redis and CDN

Developer Experience​

  • Hot Reload: Instant feedback during development
  • Type Safety: End-to-end TypeScript coverage
  • Testing: Comprehensive test suite with Vitest and Playwright
  • Linting: ESLint and Prettier for code quality
  • Git Hooks: Automated quality checks with Husky

Production Ready​

  • Docker: Multi-stage builds for optimization
  • CI/CD: GitHub Actions for automated testing and deployment
  • Monitoring: Health checks and error tracking
  • Scalability: Horizontal scaling with load balancers

Getting Started​

Getting started is simple:

git clone https://github.com/tamnk74/nextjs-for-prod.git
cd nextjs-for-prod
pnpm install
pnpm dev

Visit our Setup Guide for detailed installation instructions.

What's Next?​

We're continuously improving the project with:

  • Mobile App: React Native companion app
  • Advanced Analytics: Enhanced reporting dashboard
  • AI Integration: Smart content recommendations
  • Workflow Automation: Custom workflow builder

Contributing​

We welcome contributions! Check out our Contributing Guide to get started.

Learn More​

  • Documentation
  • Architecture Guide
  • API Reference
  • GitHub Repository

This project represents months of research, development, and refinement to create a truly production-ready Next.js application. We hope it serves as a valuable reference for your own projects.

Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

Here are a few tips you might find useful.

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

  • 2019-05-30-welcome.md
  • 2019-05-30-welcome/index.md

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

The blog supports tags as well!

And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.
